channel.title: migration on Lunaapahkiing Princeton Timetree
channel.description: Recent content in migration on Lunaapahkiing Princeton Timetree

item.title: Brotherton Refusal and Collapse
item.description: Brotherton Indians release statement of refusal to leave New Jersey after Oneidas in Stockbridge, New York and invite Brotherton’s members to join them. By 1802, however, the 80 remaining residents successfully petition the state legislature for permission to sell their land and use the funds to move to Oneida Lake in New York. Passage about the Oneidas from a 1797 book written by Jedediah Morse. Passage about the Oneidas from a 1797 book written by Jedediah Morse.

item.title: Cheswold, DE
item.description: ﻿Area known as “Cheswold” in Kent County, Delaware (92 miles from Princeton) becomes a village of coalescing Lunaape and Nanticoke families.

item.title: Colonial Alliances
item.description: Most New Jersey Lunaape and Lunaapeew reject the invitation from western Delawares to join them in the Ohio Valley. In the mid-late 1700s, the eve of American Revolutionary War, most Delaware groups are living along Ohio and Allegheny rivers. Pro-British Delawares live in what is today northwestern Ohio, and pro-American Delawares near the frontier city of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

item.title: Kansas
item.description: Delaware Tribe moves from White River, Indiana, to Kansas (junction of Kansas and Missouri rivers). View a photograph of “Delaware Indians” between 1860 and 1865.

item.title: Munsee in Wisconsin
item.description: Small groups of Christian Munsee and Unami converts remaining along the Hudson and Delaware River valleys relocate with Munsee and Mahicans living in Stockbridge, Massachusetts, to a reservation in Wisconsin. They are recognized today as Stockbridge-Munsee Band of Mohican Indians. Among those who moved to Wisconsin was Bartholemew Calvin who matriculated at the College of New Jersey in 1774. Passage about the Stockbridge Lenape moving to Wisconsin in a Princeton Herald passage written in April 1963 by John Cunningham.

item.title: Ohio Migration
item.description: A majority of Munsee and Unami speakers join villages along the Susquehanna, Allegheny, and Ohio rivers (known as Ohio Country) and are referred to collectively as the Delaware. Refugees are obliged to live as protectorates of the Six Nations/Iroquois. The Delawares experience pressure to centralize authority and elect a representative chief, which threatens their clan-based system of shared authority.

item.title: Ontario Munsee
item.description: Following the American Revolution in the late 1700s, some pro-British Munsee groups living in northwestern Ohio during the American Revolution migrate to Munceytown along Thames River (Ontario). They were known previously as the Munsee of the Thames.

item.title: Seneca Nation
item.description: A group of predominantly Munsee settle with the Seneca along the Allegheny River. Today they constitute the assimilated members of the Seneca Nation of Indians located on Allegheny Indian Reservation in southwestern New York. View a map showing Seneca Nation.

item.title: Unami Migration
item.description: Southern New Jersey Lënape migrate to Pennsylvania with the Nanticokes.

item.title: Westward Migration
item.description: The Walking Purchase is a key event in the forced migration of southern Lunaape communities westward into Ohio Country, shaping Lunaape/British relations for decades to follow. A 1765 engraving by Thomas Hutchins showing where American military forces marched in a section of the Ohio River Valley, where native tribes were living.Library of Congress
